content: No, not really but when you see this you might wish there was some. At a public event some guy who thinks he's a wizard gets buck naked. The cops start out by trying to nicely convince him to put his clothes back on but he consistently refuses. This guy has absolutely no reason to ever want to get naked in public. One look at the family jewels will show that he comes from an extremely poor family. Anyway, the cops try until they realize he's an azzhole. Then they put on the blue rubber gloves and things get ugly. When cops ask you nicely to stop breaking the law, maybe you should do that. >http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2009/04/23/naked-wizard-tazered-at-c_n_190502.html

content: I didn't see the video or read a link. I'm not sure if the man was mentally deranged or just a teenager conducting a prank. An experienced homicide detective explained to me it's not unusual for someone high on PCP or Angel Dust to disrobe and act irrationally before they die. These facts must be considered when investigating claims of brutality against cops, fire fighters, and first responders. Everyone tends to look upon others for blame. Law enforcement recieves the most of it. Most of the accusations are from those with no experience in dealing with the situations described.

content: Police are not involved in repossessions. That's a civil matter where vendors are hired by a bank or finance company. Many of these repo people look like they're suspects themselves. Back to the original post, anybody appearing in public naked as described here poses a significant concern to me. He may just be the type of person who intends on disarming a cop and using his weapon on the officer and others. I don't get hurt for anybody. My police academy training says the taser is "minimum use of force". If a tort action follows, I will be safe following my original training. I know I'm not right all the time and these boards should encourage discussions. Thanks for letting me contribute to more than just the weather.
